Civilization VI is that beautiful, evil game that convinces you you‚Äôre just going to play ‚Äúone more turn‚Äù ‚Äî and then the sun comes up, your coffee‚Äôs cold, and Cleopatra has declared war because you built a wonder too close to her pyramid selfie spot.

You start with a single settler and a dream, and before long you‚Äôre managing an empire so complex you need a spreadsheet, three advisors, and possibly divine intervention. Every turn feels like a brilliant plan ‚Äî until you realize you‚Äôve spent 200 years building libraries while Montezuma turns your borders into a parking lot.

The cartoony art style hides a terrifyingly deep strategy game. Districts make city planning feel like Sudoku for psychopaths, diplomacy is still a chaotic mess of broken promises and passive-aggressive denunciations, and natural disasters exist solely to punish your hubris right after you finish the Pyramids.

And yet‚Ä¶ it‚Äôs perfect. The soundtrack swells, your cities glow, and you feel like an omnipotent genius ‚Äî even if your entire empire is starving because you forgot farms exist.

Civilization VI isn‚Äôt just a game ‚Äî it‚Äôs a time thief, a history simulator, and a cautionary tale about overconfidence in urban planning.

[h2]Sid Meier‚Äôs Civilization VI - A Strategic Review[/h2]

[h3]Overview[/h3]

With over 500 hours in Civilization VI, I can confidently say it remains one of the most enduring and rewarding 4X experiences. As someone who gravitates toward cultural and diplomatic victories, I‚Äôve found Civ VI exceptionally good at rewarding long-term planning. The thrill lies in growing a single city into a global civilization through culture, science, diplomacy, religion, or conquest. Each victory path brings unique challenges, and while I prefer peaceful builds, domination runs can be equally exhilarating. After countless playthroughs, Civ VI still stands out as a deep and engaging strategy game.

[h3]Core Mechanics and City-Building[/h3]

Civ VI‚Äôs city-building revolves around its district system. Cities physically expand across hexes, requiring players to think about terrain, adjacency, and city specialization. A Theater Square thrives next to wonders; an Industrial Zone gains power near mines. This design forces meaningful decisions and ensures each city feels distinct. The Eureka and Inspiration system further enhances pacing, rewarding exploration and development with partial boosts to technologies and civics. Together, these mechanics create a satisfying loop of expansion, optimization, and strategic pacing through the early and mid-game.

[h3]Leaders and Civilization Design[/h3]

The game‚Äôs diverse leaders and civilizations are one of its biggest strengths. Each civ has abilities that push you toward specific strategies, making every run feel unique. Greece leans into culture, Mali into gold, Japan into compact districts‚Äîeach playstyle is genuinely different. Leader agendas shape diplomacy with personality-driven behavior that gives interactions more flavor. Expansions introduce civs like the MƒÅori or Sweden, offering even more variety. With dozens of leaders available, mastering their strengths becomes a long-term part of Civ VI‚Äôs appeal.

[h3]Diplomacy and World Systems[/h3]

Diplomacy evolves meaningfully across eras. Early tensions can develop into alliances, pacts, and interdependence. The World Congress (with expansions) creates a global stage where resolutions and emergencies matter. City-states provide powerful suzerainty bonuses, making diplomatic maneuvering essential‚Äîespecially for Diplomatic Victory. Religion adds another competitive layer, enabling both cooperation and conflict as players spread faith through missionaries, apostles, and theological combat. The race for Great People creates constant global competition, and securing the right figure at the right moment can drastically tilt your strategy.

[h3]Strategic Depth and Victory Paths[/h3]

Civ VI offers multiple win conditions, each requiring a tailored strategy. Cultural Victory focuses on tourism, wonders, and great works; Diplomatic Victory revolves around World Congress influence and global leadership. Science Victory pushes you to build a strong research and production economy, while Domination Victory tests your military planning and resource management. Religious Victory offers a unique spiritual conquest route. What makes Civ VI shine is the freedom to pivot mid-game depending on circumstances, creating dynamic, replayable sessions full of strategic adaptation.

[h3]Expansions and Long-Term Replayability[/h3]

Rise and Fall and Gathering Storm transform the game with mechanics like Loyalty, Golden/Dark Ages, Governors, climate change, natural disasters, and the revamped World Congress. These systems deepen the mid- and late-game, making peaceful and diplomatic play more compelling. Gathering Storm‚Äôs environmental effects and diplomatic victory condition especially enrich long-term play. The New Frontier Pass adds new civs and game modes‚Äîlike Secret Societies, Heroes & Legends, Dramatic Ages, and Monopolies‚Äîallowing players to customize their experience and keep the game fresh. With the Anthology version, Civ VI becomes a massive strategic sandbox with remarkable replayability.

[h3]Conclusion and Recommendation[/h3]

After years of updates, Civilization VI stands as one of the most complete and satisfying strategy games available. Its blend of empire-building, diplomacy, warfare, and cultural development offers depth few games can match. The expansions elevate the experience significantly, making the late-game more meaningful and dynamic. While the AI can still falter and large maps slow down late turns, these issues don't diminish the overall excellence. Civ VI remains a must-play for strategy fans and a game that truly embodies the spirit of ‚Äúone more turn.‚Äù

[b]Score: 9/10[/b]. Even in 2025, Civilization VI‚Äîwith all its content‚Äîis a crown jewel of the genre.

Sid Meier‚Äôs Civilization VI delivers an expansive turn-based strategy experience that invites players to guide a civilisation from its earliest days to the modern era. The game provides considerable depth while maintaining an accessible structure that encourages experimentation. Its pacing allows for thoughtful decision-making, ensuring each choice feels impactful. The result is an engaging strategy title that sustains interest over long sessions.
The narrative is less a traditional storyline and more a tapestry created through the rise and fall of empires. Each leader introduces unique historical flavour, adding context to diplomatic interactions and cultural development. The progression of eras gives the sense of an evolving world shaped by player-driven events. This flexible narrative approach keeps the experience dynamic and memorable.
Gameplay centres around strategic planning, resource management, and careful diplomacy. Each system interlocks effectively, allowing multiple viable paths to victory, from cultural dominance to scientific progress. While the AI can be inconsistent in its decision-making, the variety of mechanics ensures that each playthrough feels distinct. The level of strategic freedom remains one of the game‚Äôs strongest features.
The visual presentation is vibrant, adopting a stylised aesthetic that suits the game‚Äôs accessible yet deep nature. Units, environments, and structures are clear and readable, which supports strategic play. Subtle animations and detailed leader designs contribute to the overall charm. The visual clarity ensures that even complex maps remain easy to navigate.
Overall, Sid Meier‚Äôs Civilization VI stands as a rich and rewarding strategy experience that balances depth with approachability. Its blend of emergent storytelling, varied gameplay systems, and distinctive visuals makes it a compelling entry in the long-running series. Despite occasional AI shortcomings, the diverse strategic options keep the game engaging throughout. It remains a strong recommendation for those seeking thoughtful, long-form strategy.
Sid Meier‚Äôs Civilization VI gets a 6/10.

Such an awkward step from the other civ games. Decided to properly have a sit down with all of them this weekend, definitely love these games a lot now. I just really don't see where civ vi fits in.

civ V was easily my favorite, it had such an overbearing weighty design from the baritone narrators voice to the grandness of the design around the ui. 

Vi's style is definitely different, and not in a bad way. I think the direction of leaning more into the aspect of the perspective and goals of the representation having a slightly more cartoony or plastic toy art style is cute! I think if they utilized the exaggeration to the point of history itself being such a wild and outlandish thing and did so through it's representation of everything it's giving you this would have been great. Unfortunately it makes the fog of war, not fog, but dissolving paper. Hex grids feel less like miniature dioramas and more like I'm playing settlers of catan with wooden figures on my table at home. It doesn't feel grand or exaggerated, just that there's more clarity and its simplified and not in a way that serves what I felt was the point of civ. I do appreciate it for the quality of life with finding resources or knowing what's going on, but it feels all round like a step down for running inherently worse somehow.

As for the actual game, I did praise the clarity and I do like a lot of the quality of life changes. I like how the trade routes do automatic roads so you don't need to create 50 builders standing in a line to make a road that'll appear in like 3-6 turns. Plus it helps new players get more into what was always more daunting for me, the trade aspect. I like some of the new ideas, the environmental disasters is an interesting concept that I think was pushed much further than it needed to be. I think the hero units conceptually is cool, although I feel conflict was all-round brought down which makes it tricky for them being interesting units when they fade after a set amount of turns. It funnily had me imagining an xcom-style fate/grand order game. I think having the modifiers for different types of games with goals like survival in the zombie and environmental apocalypse mode is really cool I also liked the change for cavalry horse units being melee only, while the archery chariots were neat in V they were a lot more niche than they needed to be. 

All that being said there's just too much to dislike. You can't cross borders to trigger minor annoyance, instead it'll hard block your units, not even allowing you to cross a one hex tile as a single through-the-border action. Diplomacy and management had a massive glow-up of options, it's all almost completely unnecessary. It suffers from the paradox problem of giving far too many complicated menus with paragraphs of reading for little pay-off, like yeah if I shuffle my deck of cards called envoys to assign them to one of the 12 city states to get a minor boost that I then need to combo with my roguelike-deck-builder policy cards that'll make my envoys gain a bit more of a bonus I could gain an extra +2 faith! Wooooow. Keeping track of your influence, culture and faith all feels like it's in the background of the other games nearly as a hidden stat you shouldn't pay too much attention too until it fucks you over, here it's in your face but so annoying and awkward you wish you could ignore it. If anything needed simplification or more directness it was this. 
Tradings a nightmare too, they scrunched up the trade menu to take up only a quarter of the screen so they could show off the single character model for the leader you're talking too, not enough love was put into the interface there. I accidentally banned any mention of marble in a trade talk too by accident since I was trying to remove it from being on the table. They have two small x's right next to eachother, one of them is to ban it permanently, it's the monsters vs aliens big red button all over again.

Ope that's right, diplomacy with leaders is twice as much work for half the fun and quadruple the annoyance. Say goodbye to occasional talks for only gain, now you'll get insulted constantly! Yay :> hope you aren't too annoyed by a speech window popping up all the goddamn time.

I never mentioned but builders now to make up for not building roads have limited charges, they disappear after constructing around 2 or 3 things. Now you'll have to keep up the build queue to be able to put all those farms and mines down if you want the production time of the stuff you actually need built to not take 35 turns! In reality this reduces the clutter of all the builder units and makes the construction time instant, so it's more of a transfer of how long it takes to build stuff to the city build queue. While it's intended as a QOL change for that reason, it really just makes the game feel slower because it feels like you're constantly stopping the game to keep up the builder creation. It's not helped by how long it takes everything to happen either, it felt less like one more turn to get to a certain point and more like one more turn to see if anything would fucking happen. I kept getting tempted to try to maybe just attack the random countries units just to see how long it would take for a war to actually start progressing or if I should just hope a barbarian camp is somewhere nearby just so my units can stop wandering around. I'm already friends with everyone nearby, I have my envoys and diplomats doing their thing. I'm trade partners with almost everyone and it's not even the middle ages. It just felt like I already won because what's going to change when I reach the 1900's? I'm trading... even more?

there's no threat, there's nothing to think about, it's just waiting for  more construction because the barbarians can't manage anything like in 3 or 4, the empires aren't really that ambitious if you leave them enough room and and you can't really make a vye for power because you'll be too busy micromanaging your city districts to keep your city loyal and happy so they don't rebel, it's not like you can buy cities from other nations since you'll be spending them on said construction projects plus even if you did manage to proccur a few thousand gold, they're not going to be willing to trade a city anyways because the ai is just fucked.

I wish this was just either all in on being a genuine fucked up paradox game or half stepped from between what this is and what v is with polish on the ideas that didn't work out like the diplomacy and weather. I've played Civ for decades by this point. Civilization 6 is such a departure from the formula that I hate it. Disparate systems bloat the game, making it less streamlined than ever. Manage every tile within your borders to make "districts" or wonders or improvements (instead of just improvements). Faith and physical combat systems (instead of just physical with religion granting bonuses). An espionage system that features micro-managing individual districts per city (which never worked well, to be honest). Two tech trees in policy and science (instead of science unlocking policies and eras). "Accumulating" resources (instead of a straight check on if it is available). A byzantine scoring system that dictates whether you get a dark or golden age (instead of accumulated happiness).

Maybe all this additional complexity is a plus to you, and I wish you all the fun with this game. It isn't for me, and I want to make sure other Civ vets who see it on sale know what they are getting into. This is not at all similar to the old days of dropping a city on a hex, constructing buildings as they become available, and ensuring your workers are developing your tiles correctly.

While it does have some interesting innovations, it's overall a downgrade from Civ V. The district system takes away from some of the core fun of the Civ concept, and changes to Wonders take away one of the more exciting aspects of the franchise.

DO NOT BUY CIV 6!!!  The best Civilization game so far is Civ 5, hands down.  Civ 6 - while very pretty with a decent user interface - is a degraded version of Civ 5.  The gameplay is a huge disappointment that includes the following myriad of problems:
1.  District zone management massively overcomplicates city design, placement, and management.
2.  The diplomacy system is a hot mess with way too many options that make voting and policy making ineffective.
3.  Land unit movement is severely retarded to only one hex per turn on most terrain types (hills, forest, jungle, desert, marshes, etc.).
4.  Barbarians start off with military units that are at least one generation of military tech more advanced than your own.
5.  Bonuses from governors and secret societies are so-so at best.
6.  Worker units in Civ 6 go away after only 3 uses/projects in the beginning of the game, which is unlike Civ 5 where they can operate indefinitely to enhance resources and build roads anywhere.  Also, roads between cities in Civ 6 can only be built using traders, which is just...what?!?!
7.  Overall, Civ 6 a huge disappointment compared to Civ 5 and definitely a precursor to the epic failure that is Civ 7.
